executive_summary: The Plumbing Service Franchises industry includes franchised outlets that provide services such as installing and maintaining plumbing fixtures, fittings and equipment. The industry's performance is directly linked to building construction markets and consumer spending levels. The industry also benefits from stable demand from homes and businesses that need repair and maintenance of water delivery systems. Maintenance work accounts for a sizable share of demand and is a stable source of revenue when construction markets fluctuate. Consequently, increases in residential construction activity and private spending on home improvements have benefited industry operators. In fact, the substantial reduction of interest rates amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic has been the driving force behind growth in the residential construction sector. However, despite favorable interest rates, nonresidential construction projects were halted and postponed due to government mandated establishment closures and restrictions. Still, increased demand throughout the majority of the five years to 2021 has benefited plumbing franchises.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Similar to most industries linked to the residential construction sector, demand for industry services has expanded during the five-year period. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, unemployment remained relatively lower than its historical norm, which boosted per capita disposable income. As per capita disposable income increased, consumers felt relatively more comfortable in their financial situations, which led to an increase in consumer spending.

However, the coronavirus pandemic in 2020 significantly hampered activity within the nonresidential construction sector. Establishments were forced to close down to curtail the spread of the virus, resulting in historical levels of unemployment. As a result, activity within the nonresidential building market significantly reduced, as businesses were not able to properly function and thus demand from the commercial sector contracted.

Overall, elevated demand throughout the majority of the period and a continuously healthy residential construction market is estimated to have offset recent declines in nonresidential construction activity. Consequently, industry revenue is anticipated to rise an annualized 2.5% to $1.4 billion over the five years to 2021.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, the 30-year conventional mortgage rate is projected to increase 1.7 percentage points, reaching an estimated 4.8% in 2026. Since home building and renovation projects take a relatively short amount of time to complete, the level of activity within the residential building market is highly susceptible to the price of financing. Overall, the value of residential construction is expected to decrease at an annualized rate of 0.9% over the next five years.

Aside from residential market potential, demand from the nonresidential sector is forecast to reverse negative trends of the previous five-year period and return to significant growth. Overall, the value of private nonresidential construction is projected to increase at an annualized rate of 2.7% over the next five years.
Overall, industry revenue is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 0.6% to $1.4 billion over the five years to 2026.

industry_definition: This industry operates franchised plumbing service companies. Reports in our Business Franchise collection focus solely on the operation of franchised outlets and exclude non-franchise data. They show the total number of franchise outlets, total franchise revenue and the average profit margins earned by franchisees.
key_trends: Demand from the nonresidential construction sector is estimated to have declined in 2020 amid the coronavirus pandemic
Strong growth in the residential building and renovation markets boosted revenue

market_segmentation.segment_description: The residential market includes work done for new construction, which typically involves repair and maintenance work or renovation of already-installed plumbing systems.
Healthcare, education and institutional buildings include hospitals, medical complexes, courts, prisons, police stations and schools.

The retail market consists of a diverse set of buildings and companies, including restaurants, automobile service stations, boutique stores, grocers and big-box retailers. Additionally, this segment includes distribution centers and mini-storage units.
The residential market includes work done for existing structures, which typically involves repair and maintenance work or renovation of already-installed plumbing systems.

The manufacturing and industrial building sector requires plumbing specialists for water and other standard plumbing systems as well as other forms of liquid and gas piping that are used in industrial processes.

products_and_services.product_description: General plumbing services are estimated to contribute 53.8% of the Plumbers industry revenue in 2021. These services include the installation, repair and maintenance of water distribution pipes and appliances, water heaters, garbage disposals, bathroom and kitchen sinks, water pipes and other plumbing.

Mechanical services contribute an estimated 34.4% of revenue in 2021. Mechanical contracting services consist primarily of the installation of mechanical and process piping and tubing. These include main lines that convey hot and cold water, steam, medical gas, fuels and other liquids and gases, in addition to the installation of related equipment and fixtures that store, pump, regulate and measure the distribution of these substances.

Aside from general plumbing and mechanical services, plumbing contractors also generate revenue through sprinkler system installations, which are expected to contribute 8.2% of annual revenue in 2021. These sprinkler systems can be related to both commercial properties, such as an office building's fire-protection systems and residential properties, in the form of lawn sprinklers.

tier_1_suppliers: Tool & Hardware Wholesaling in the US
Plumbing & Heating Supplies Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Real Estate and Rental and Leasing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Plumbing & Heating Supplies Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Housing affordability, including prevailing and expected mortgage interest rates; demographic factors, such as population growth and household formation trends; and economic factors, including employment growth and household income, all determine the need for new residential construction. As the number of new residential properties rises, the pool of potential customers for the industry grows.

In the nonresidential building markets, the overall health of the business sector and the level of consumer spending directly determine the need for new offices, retail centers, warehouses and other buildings that require plumbing installations. Investment into healthcare, education and other institutional buildings is largely driven by population growth and government spending.

Maintenance activity or repair of existing properties across all markets generates a significant portion of industry revenue and is often undertaken on a fixed-period contract basis for commercial customers (e.g. supermarkets and warehouses) and on an irregular basis in the residential market or by referral from gas marketing agents or others.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The Plumbing Service Franchises industry is service oriented and there is no international trade within this industry as goods are not passed from one country to another.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region accounts for 25.7% of industry establishments, which corresponds with the region's share of US population, 25.8%. Florida drives this region with 7.8% of industry establishments, reflecting its highly developed housing market.

The Mid-Atlantic region, which includes the populations of New York City and Philadelphia, accounts for 16.4% of industry establishments. The Mid-Atlantic region exhibits greater demand for plumbing maintenance services to support the region's large manufacturing base and aging building stock, which includes a high number of historical buildings. New York has the fourth-highest share of industry establishments (6.8% of the national total) due to its lucrative commercial and multifamily residential construction markets.

The West region accounts for a disproportionately low share of industry activity relative to the region's share of the national population and economy. The West region accounts for 14.8% of industry establishments while representing 17.2% of the total US population. However, California has the most establishments per state at 10.1%.

The Great Lakes region accounts for 13.0% of industry establishments, corresponding with the region's share of the national population, which is 14.4%. The region exhibits this high demand for industry services due to the heavy industrial base centered in Illinois (fifth largest share of establishments by state, 4.0%), Ohio and Michigan.

The Southwest region accounts for 11.6% of industry establishments, which corresponds with the region's share of the national population (12.8%). Texas has the third-largest share of establishments with 7.5% and represents 8.8% of the nation's population.

The Plains region is estimated to account for 7.0% establishments and 6.5% of the US population. Low population density in the Plains region means that more establishments are required to serve a given number of households or businesses, whereas in densely populated urban areas, one establishment can serve more consumers in a smaller locale.

The New England region's share of industry establishments (6.3%) exceeds the states' combined share of the US population. Harsh winters common to these regions mean consistent piping repair work for industry operators located there.

The Rocky Mountains region's share of industry establishments (5.2%) exceeds the states' combined share of the US population. Harsh winters common to these regions mean consistent piping repair work for industry operators located there.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Most states require plumbers to be licensed, which typically requires experience and passing an examination testing knowledge of the trade and local codes.
Contractors are subject to laws and regulations governing remediation of contaminated soil and groundwater administered by the EPA and state/local agencies.
Services are subject to industry standards approved by ANSI and codes like the Uniform Plumbing Code produced by IAPMO covering installation requirements.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Initial investment required for potential entrants
barriers_points.barrier_description: Initial investment required for potential entrants poses a major barrier to entry; costs include a one-time start-up fee and royalty payments to the franchiser, along with capital equipment costs.

Licensing regulations and legal necessities pose a barrier to entry. Licensing certification and qualification requirements vary by state, county and city, restricting movement between markets and confining industry operators to certain locations.
Competition can prevent new entrants from establishing a presence in the industry, as existing contractors have brand recognition, established reputation and price-competitiveness.

basis_points.basis_description: Operators primarily compete on price and quality of service. As disposable income decreases, a greater focus is placed on price-based competition within the industry.

basis_points.basis_title: Technological innovations and securing competitively priced inputs
basis_points.basis_description: Technological innovations and securing contracts for competitively priced inputs are central to companies acquiring a competitive edge.

basis_points.basis_title: Quality of service for generating repeat business
basis_points.basis_description: Quality of service is an extremely important component of competition in the industry. Generating repeat clients and favorable feedback through word-of-mouth and online reviews is key to developing a steady revenue base.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 3 players account for 62.5% market share in 2021
concentration_points.concentration_description: IBISWorld estimates that in 2021 the top three players are expected to account for 62.5% of available market share, giving the Plumbing Service Franchises industry a moderate level of market share concentration.

Due to established investments with the parent company and economies of scale in contract maintenance, the largest franchisees tend to receive preferential treatment from the parent companies through access to new and prime locations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The industry is highly labor intensive; plumbing is primarily a learned skill that cannot be performed by automated machinery or technology.
Purchases account for the largest expense for industry operators and include materials like pipes, tools, fuels and lubricants.
Most franchises also have an initial franchise fee, which generally ranges from $25,000 to $100,000.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry requires a low level of capital investment, with most costs pertaining to labor, purchases, and benefits.
Capital costs vary for each location and each franchisee, with most franchisors offering different financing options based on the capital requirements of each new establishment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital expenses mainly for vehicles and tools
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital expenses mainly consist of vehicles and rudimentary tools, which are usually accumulated in an apprenticeship or can also be rented.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is affected by cyclical fluctuations in overall US construction markets, especially residential construction which accounts for 43.3% of revenue.
Volatility is kept in check by long-term maintenance contracts for large facilities and overall demand for pipe and drain repair that cannot be easily delayed.
Revenue declined 3.6% in 2020 amid the COVID-19 pandemic, but is expected to expand further as the economy reopens.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Traditional materials are being replaced by more flexible substitutes like plastic and aluminum, but this shift is nearing the end of its cycle.
Plumbing work relies heavily on skilled manual labor rather than technological knowledge, with little labor-saving equipment fundamentally changing the industry.
Some new technology like plumbing inspection cameras is enabling plumbers to more accurately determine causes of issues like clogged pipes.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or nonresidential construction markets? Can you easily switch between these markets?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with both residential and nonresidential construction markets, since their service offerings easily transfer from one type of building to the next.

FAQs.question: Does your company plan on investing in autonomous vehicles in the near future to reduce labor costs?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry are not expected to invest in autonomous vehicles in the near future, but are expected to invest in new vehicles in general in order to maximize their efficiency.

FAQs.question: Investment in new technology is usually fairly low among builders and contractors. How much does your company invest in new equipment annually?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry do not invest significantly in new equipment, with depreciation costs accounting for an expected 0.9% in 2018.

FAQs.question: How does your company streamline workflow when dealing with conflicting local and state regulations?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry follow regulatory guidelines to ensure they are not breaking any regulations.

FAQs.question: Has complying with new energy-efficiency rules in various building codes driven up costs? How has your company offset these increases?
FAQs.answer: New energy-efficiency rules have not significantly driven up costs for industry operators.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Company profit margins typically account for 2.0-10.0% of revenue. The average industry profit margin, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is anticipated to account for 5.6% of revenue in 2021, up from 5.3% in 2016.

FAQs.question: How many of your clients are return customers?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry benefit from referrals, which makes return customers frequent in this industry.

FAQs.question: Where are your establishments located? Do your stores experience heavy traffic? Are they located in proximity to competitors?
FAQs.answer: It is important for industry establishments to be conveniently located near key customer markets.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor quality in your operations? Do you have training in place to ensure employees are informed of quality standards?
FAQs.answer: It is critical to have experience and skills in managing and operating all aspects of a small business to achieve financial success.

FAQs.question: How have you established and developed your reputation? How do you set your company apart from others?
FAQs.answer: Having a good reputation for a high level of technical knowledge of the services and end-user needs can be a competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: How has the 30-year conventional mortgage rate affected your company? What can you do when it increases?
FAQs.answer: The 30-year conventional mortgage rate represents the average interest rate offered on a mortgage by commercial banks. As the 30-year conventional mortgage rate increases, so too does the cost of buying a home.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor and respond to revenue and profit trends in nonresidential construction? How do you take advantage when the value increases?
FAQs.answer: This industry is sensitive to the cyclical fluctuations of investment in nonresidential building construction. An increase in the value of private nonresidential construction typically benefits plumbing franchisees.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor housing starts? How do you take advantage when housing starts increase? How do you adapt when they decrease?
FAQs.answer: Industry revenue is derived from work on new single-family homes. As the number of houses built per year increases, demand for the installation of plumbing and related work increases.
